--- In junit@y..., Ilja Preu=DF <ilja.preuss@w...> wrote:
> What exactly do=
es the @pre tag do? Does it test that the method 
fails if called with an i=
nvalid value?

Hi,

The @pre tag is used for jtest, it does a couple things=
... Helps to 
constrain the generated input args and helps to check relatio=
nship 
behavior between classes.

For example, if the method throws excepti=
on when Vector size is 
greater than 10 (exception found by Jtest), the dev=
eloper says, 
vector size is handled by the caller and is never going to be=
 beyond 
a certain range (an implied precondition -- every method has impli=
ed 
contracts)...the contract can be made explicit so that it may be 
check=
ed programmatically as in below:

/**
 * @pre vector_arg.size () <=3D 10
 *=
/

u can also do things like:

/**
 * @pre callMyMethodToCheckStateIsOK () =
=3D=3D true
 */

And that method can do things like check db connection and=
 so forth.

Jtest will constrain it's input generation so it does not viola=
te the 
@pre condition.  Contracts can also validate through class 
relatio=
nships, for example:

If "class A" calls methods in "class B" and Jtest is =
testing "class 
A", IT WILL TRY to generate input to A's methods which brea=
k B's 
contracts, hence letting you know there is a possibilty that the 
cl=
ass relationship is not well defined...let me know if u need more 
elaborat=
ion on this point.

Carson
ParaSoft Support

> 
> > --- In junit@y..., "rxq=
ch" <rxqch@y...> wrote:

 answer to the

n javadoc to find such 
> > > problems.
